title: Non-Discrimination and Anti-Harassment Policy
summary: University policy prohibiting harassment and discrimination based on protected status, establishing procedures for reporting and investigating complaints, and defining rights and responsibilities of all parties
commitment: The University of Georgia is committed to maintaining a fair and respectful environment for living, work, and study. The University prohibits harassment of or discrimination against any person based on protected status by any member of the University Community.

related_policies.note: This Policy incorporates by reference applicable sections of USG policies. All discrimination and harassment allegations (except Sexual Misconduct against student respondents) covered by this Policy together with USG policies.

university_community_members: University faculty, staff, administrators, employees, and independent contractors
Volunteers and participants in any University program or activity
Guests and visitors to campus or any property owned/leased by the University or University-affiliated organizations

sexual_misconduct.description: Umbrella term for wide range of prohibited sexual conduct including sexual harassment. Can occur regardless of relationship, position, or respective sex. Same-sex harassment violates this policy, as does harassment by student of employee or subordinate of supervisor.
sexual_misconduct.sexual_harassment_non_student: Unwelcome verbal, nonverbal, or physical conduct based on sex (including gender stereotypes) that may be: (1) implicitly/explicitly a term or condition of employment or status in course/program/activity; (2) basis for employment or educational decisions; (3) sufficiently severe, persistent, or pervasive to interfere with work/educational performance creating intimidating, hostile, or offensive environment; or (4) determined by reasonable person to be so severe, pervasive, and objectively offensive that it effectively denies equal access to University education program or activity in violation of Title IX
sexual_misconduct.sexual_harassment_student_on_student: Unwelcome verbal, nonverbal, or physical conduct based on sex (including gender stereotypes), determined by reasonable person to be so severe, pervasive, and objectively offensive that it effectively denies equal access to participate in or benefit from institutional education program or activity
examples: Nonconsensual touching of another's body, including unwanted hugging or shoulder rubbing
Sexual remarks, jokes, anecdotes, inquiries, or physical gestures
Requests or propositions of a sexual nature
Gender/sex-based comments about physique, clothing, or sexual/romantic activity or preferences
Inappropriate use, display, or non-consensual sharing of sexual images, text, or objects

additional_prohibited_conduct.dating_violence: Violence by person who is or has been in romantic/intimate social relationship with alleged victim. Includes sexual or physical abuse or threat thereof. Determined based on: length of relationship, type of relationship, frequency of interaction. Does not include acts under domestic violence definition.
additional_prohibited_conduct.domestic_violence: Violence by current/former spouse or intimate partner; person with whom victim shares a child; person cohabitating/has cohabitated with victim as spouse/intimate partner; or person similarly situated to spouse
additional_prohibited_conduct.nonconsensual_sexual_contact: Any physical contact with another person of sexual nature without consent. Includes touching of intimate parts (genitalia, groin, breasts, buttocks); touching person with one's own intimate parts; forcing person to touch own or another's intimate parts. Includes 'Fondling' as defined by Clery Act.
additional_prohibited_conduct.nonconsensual_sexual_penetration: Any penetration of vagina, anus, or mouth by penis, object, tongue, finger, or other body part; or contact between mouth and genitals/anus of another. Includes 'Rape, Incest, and Statutory Rape' as defined by Clery Act.
additional_prohibited_conduct.sexual_assault: Term used in Clery Act to refer to offense classified as forcible or nonforcible sex offense under FBI uniform crime reporting system
additional_prohibited_conduct.stalking: Engaging in course of conduct directed at specific person that would cause reasonable person to fear for safety or suffer substantial emotional distress. Course of conduct means 2+ acts including following, monitoring, observing, surveilling, threatening, or communicating to/about person or interfering with property. Pertains to conduct with sexual intent in dating relationship or attempts at establishing sexual/dating relationship or conduct after relationship has ended.
additional_prohibited_conduct.sexual_exploitation: Taking non-consensual or abusive sexual advantage of another for one's own advantage/benefit or benefit of anyone other than the one being exploited. Examples: invasion of sexual privacy, prostituting another, non-consensual photos/video/audio of sexual activity, non-consensual distribution of sexual media, intentional observation of nonconsenting partially undressed/naked/sexually active individuals, knowingly transmitting STD/HIV, inappropriate exposure, sexually-based bullying

sexual_misconduct.consent: Words or actions showing knowing and voluntary willingness to engage in mutually agreed-upon sexual activity. Cannot be gained by force, intimidation, coercion, ignoring objections, or taking advantage of incapacitation. Minors under 16 cannot legally consent under Georgia law. Consent is absent when activity exceeds scope of previous consent. Past consent does not imply present/future consent. Silence or absence of resistance does not imply consent. Can be withdrawn at any time.
sexual_misconduct.incapacitation: Physical and/or mental inability to make informed, rational judgments. Can result from mental disability, sleep, unconsciousness, involuntary physical restraint, status as minor under 16, or intentional/unintentional taking of alcohol/drugs. Judged from perspective of objectively reasonable person.

key_definitions.discriminatory_harassment: Unwelcome verbal or physical conduct based on protected categories when sufficiently severe, persistent, or pervasive to: (1) unreasonably interfere with work or educational performance; (2) create intimidating, hostile, or offensive working or learning environment; or (3) unreasonably interfere with or limit ability to participate in or benefit from institutional program or activity
key_definitions.discrimination: Decision-making based on age, color, disability, genetic information, national origin, race, religion, sex, or veteran status. Examples: hiring/termination/promotion/salary decisions based on protected categories; assigning grades or academic decisions based on protected categories; refusing acceptance/admission to person with disability without considering accommodations

eoo_director.title: Director of Equal Opportunity Office
responsibilities: Provide education and training about prohibited discrimination and harassment
Receive and investigate reports and complaints
eoo_director.note: EOO employees do not serve as advocates or representatives for parties or witnesses

prohibition_against_retaliation.protection: Anyone who has made a report/complaint, provided information, assisted, participated, or refused to participate in NDAH Process shall not be subjected to retaliation
prohibition_against_retaliation.action: Anyone believing they experienced retaliation should immediately contact EOO Director or designee
prohibition_against_retaliation.consequence: Any person found to have engaged in retaliation shall be subject to disciplinary action

confidentiality.principle: University strongly supports individual's interest in confidentiality, particularly in instances involving sexual misconduct
confidentiality.request_consideration: When complainant/alleged victim requests identity be withheld or allegation not investigated, EOO Director/Title IX Coordinator will consider if request can be honored while complying with laws, regulations, policies and providing safe, nondiscriminatory environment
confidentiality.limitations: Honoring request may limit University's ability to respond fully and discipline respondent
confidentiality.notification: Complainant/alleged victim informed of any decision to act contrary to request before disclosures made and before investigation begins

privileged_resource_employees.description: Individuals to whom complainant/victim may talk in confidence as provided by law. Disclosure does not automatically trigger investigation against wishes. Exceptions exist for suspected abuse of minors or imminent threat of serious harm.
employees: University Health Center CAPS (Counseling and Psychiatric Services)
UGA Center for Counseling and Personal Evaluation
Wilbanks Child Endangerment and Sexual Exploitation Clinic
privileged_resource_employees.note: Must comply with anonymous reporting for Clery Act and mandatory reporting under Georgia law. Clery anonymous reporting doesn't apply to pastoral/professional counselors acting as counselors.

support_resource_employees.description: Designated to talk with complainant/respondent in confidence. Must only report that incident occurred with date, time, location, respondent name (if known) without revealing information identifying alleged victim. Minimal reporting required for Title IX and Clery Act compliance. May be required to fully disclose to ensure campus safety.
employees: University Health Center RSVP (Relationship and Sexual Violence Prevention)

responsible_employees.definition: Any administrator, supervisor, faculty member, or person in position of authority who is not Privileged or Support Resource Employee
responsible_employees.obligation: Must fully report information or complaint to EOO promptly
responsible_employees.student_employees: Teaching assistants, residential assistants, student managers, orientation leaders in supervisory/advisory/managerial roles must also promptly report
responsible_employees.failure_consequence: Failure to promptly report may constitute separate violation and provide basis for discipline

reporting.encouraged_reporting: Any person who feels discriminated against or harassed should promptly report to EOO or discuss with confidential resources. Any community member who observes discrimination/harassment should report to EOO.
reporting.confidentiality_request: If complainant wants to maintain confidentiality when reporting to Responsible Employee, employee must relay request when reporting to EOO. Request will be considered but cannot be guaranteed.
reporting.timeliness: Complaints should be reported as soon as possible after incident(s) for most effective investigation
reporting.methods: In person, in writing (via complaint form, email, or otherwise), or over phone. Under some circumstances (including Title IX complaints), EOO may require written complaint. Anonymous complaints accepted but may limit investigation extent.
reporting.criminal_conduct: Where discrimination/harassment is potentially criminal, community members encouraged to also contact UGA Police (on campus) or local law enforcement (off campus). Police not notified of sexual assault without victim's consent unless imminent threat or involves someone under 16. Mandatory reporting obligation for minors. Right to simultaneously file complaint under this Policy and with law enforcement.

false_accusations.prohibition: Individuals prohibited from knowingly making false statements or submitting false information to University official
false_accusations.consequence: Any person found to have knowingly submitted false complaints, accusations, or statements (including during hearing) subject to disciplinary action up to suspension, expulsion, or termination
false_accusations.adjudication: Students adjudicated under UGA Code of Conduct; employees under this Policy

conflicts_of_interest.definition: Financial interest, relationship, or other circumstance that would lead reasonable person to doubt objectivity of EOO representative
conflicts_of_interest.process: If actual/apparent conflict asserted, complaint submitted/referred to Office of Legal Affairs to resolve. If no conflict found, EOO conducts inquiry. If conflict found, Office of Legal Affairs (consulting President) appoints independent individual with appropriate experience/training.

academic_freedom_and_expression.commitment: University committed to protecting freedom of expression and full academic freedom of inquiry, teaching, service, and research
academic_freedom_and_expression.limitation: Policy not intended to infringe rights guaranteed by US Constitution including First Amendment free speech or Fourteenth Amendment due process, but academic freedom and expression will not excuse behavior violating law or this policy

records.open_records_act: Subject to Georgia Open Records Act (O.C.G.A. ยง50-18-70, et seq.)
records.privacy_laws: Maintained subject to privacy requirements under state and federal law, including FERPA and USG record retention policy
records.accommodations_privacy: University will take reasonable steps to maintain privacy of accommodations/protective measures except to extent necessary to provide them
records.internal_sharing: Information shared internally on need-to-know basis
records.investigative_file_access: Complainant(s) and respondent(s) allowed to review directly related information at same time they receive draft investigative report. Privileged material not voluntarily released in writing not included or considered.
records.clery_compliance: Public release for crime logs/timely warnings won't release names or information that could identify victim

advisor_or_support_person.right: Any party may use advisor (including attorney) of their choosing at their expense
advisor_or_support_person.restriction: May not select advisor who is party or witness to investigation
advisor_or_support_person.presence: Advisor may be present during meetings/proceedings in which advisee is eligible to be present
advisor_or_support_person.role: May advise advisee including providing questions, suggestions, advice on proceedings, guidance on responses, but shall not participate directly except for cross-examination in formal Title IX hearing
advisor_or_support_person.cross_examination_requirement: If party doesn't have advisor for Title IX formal hearing, University will provide one solely for cross-examination
advisor_or_support_person.communication: All communication between University and party, not advisor. Advisor may be copied on communications with party's permission and when University provides right to inspect/review investigation information.

rights_and_responsibilities.presumption_of_not_responsible: Individuals presumed not responsible for alleged conduct until determination made at conclusion of investigative and/or hearing process

amnesty_for_students.principle: Individuals encouraged to come forward and report notwithstanding consumption of alcohol or drugs
amnesty_for_students.protection: Information about student's own drug/alcohol consumption during investigation not used against student in disciplinary proceeding or voluntarily reported to law enforcement
amnesty_for_students.requirements: Students may be required to meet with staff about incident and participate in appropriate educational programs
amnesty_for_students.clarification: Required educational program participation not considered a sanction
amnesty_for_students.limitation: Doesn't prevent reporting required by law (including Clery Act)

investigation_and_resolution.overview: Procedure to investigate complaints/reports, end discrimination/harassment found, remedy effects, and prevent recurrence. May recommend informal resolution if appropriate and permitted under law. Can be carried out prior to, simultaneously with, or following civil/criminal proceedings.
investigation_and_resolution.witness_cooperation: University employees identified as witnesses required to fully cooperate. Willfully disregarding, delaying, or thwarting investigation or making false statements may result in violation finding and disciplinary action. Accused persons not required to make statement or respond, but silence considered general denial and investigation may proceed.
investigation_and_resolution.eoo_role: NDAH Officer/Title IX Coordinator or designee explains they are not advocate or representative for either party. Advocacy, counseling, and support resources identified at end of policy.
investigation_and_resolution.information_sharing: Information obtained during complaint process shared with other participants or witnesses only to extent necessary for thorough, fair, impartial investigation
investigation_and_resolution.standard_of_review: Preponderance of the evidence standard (i.e., 'more likely than not'). Information supporting alleged violation must be more convincing than information in opposition.

interim_protective_measures.authority: EOO Director/NDAH Officer/Title IX Coordinator or designee may impose before final resolution if failure would constitute threat to safety/well-being of complainant or community or to ensure equal access to education programs/activities
interim_protective_measures.respondent_opportunity: Where practicable, provide respondent initial opportunity to respond to allegations and imposition of interim measures before instituted
interim_protective_measures.not_indicative: Imposing interim measures doesn't indicate violation occurred. Designed to protect complainant and community, not harm respondent. Should minimize burden on both parties where feasible.
possible_measures: Restrictions or bars to entering certain University property
Changes to academic or employment arrangements, schedules, or supervision
Other measures designed to promote safety and well-being

interim_suspension.standard: Only where necessary to maintain safety and limited to situations where respondent poses serious and immediate danger or threat to persons or property
interim_suspension.assessment_factors: Existence of significant risk to health/safety; nature, duration, and severity of risk; probability of potential injury; whether less restrictive means can mitigate risk
interim_suspension.hearing_right: When requested by respondent, hearing with EOO Director/NDAH Officer/Title IX Coordinator within 3 business days to determine if suspension should continue. Complainant informed of request and provided opportunity to participate.

initiating_investigation.preliminary_inquiry: Upon receiving report, EOO engages in preliminary inquiry to: assess nature of report; provide outreach to complainant; offer supportive measures; determine applicable policy; determine if parties within jurisdiction; determine if report implicates safety threat; determine available/appropriate resolution
initiating_investigation.report_vs_complaint: Making report different from filing complaint. When EOO receives report, it offers supportive measures to complainant and explains process for filing complaint.

preliminary_inquiry_outcomes.description: No complaint filed and no supportive measures received. May involve referral to another unit for policy review.
Complainant receives supportive measures only and elects not to file complaint
Educational conversations or coaching which are considered non-disciplinary actions
Informal Resolution requested in complaint filed by Complainant or recommended by EOO to parties
Investigation requested in complaint filed by Complainant or investigation initiated by complaint signed by Title IX Coordinator

grounds: Report doesn't allege concern/violation within EOO's subject matter jurisdiction
Report, if true/accurate, wouldn't reach preponderance standard to be policy violation
Report within jurisdiction but evidence known/potentially available significantly short of preponderance standard
Respondent no longer enrolled/employed by University
Specific circumstances (including complainant's unwillingness/inability to participate) prevent EOO from gathering sufficient evidence
dismissal_of_report_or_complaint.consequences: Investigation or informal resolution ceases. Matter may be referred to other resolution processes or appropriate follow-up (educational conversation, informal coaching). EOO reserves right to document, require remedial measures, and reopen if additional information supports further investigation.
dismissal_of_report_or_complaint.appeal_right: Parties may appeal dismissal by notifying EOO Director/Title IX Coordinator in writing within 5 business days. Other party notified of appeal. Appeal reviewed by EOO Director/Title IX Coordinator. Outcome notification within 5 business days. Can uphold or reverse dismissal. If reversed, investigative or informal resolution resumes. Appeal outcome is final.

informal_process.description: Opportunity to bring resolution through awareness, education, and/or facilitated discussion
informal_process.appropriateness: If parties and EOO Director/NDAH Officer/Title IX Coordinator or designee agree it's appropriate
informal_process.not_available: When student alleges Sexual Misconduct against employee
informal_process.fact_finding: May occur to extent necessary to resolve conflict and protect parties and community
informal_process.terms: Must stop prohibited behavior, restore/preserve environment free from prohibited conduct, and prevent reoccurrence
informal_process.exit_option: Either party can end informal process and request formal process anytime before agreement
informal_process.failed_informal_process: Not a factor in formal resolution process
possible_resolutions: Changes to work or academic arrangements
Informal discussion with person whose conduct could rise to violation level
Advisory discussion with respondent's supervisor, professor, or advisor
'No contact' directive to one or more parties
Sanctions as defined by this Policy or Code of Conduct
informal_process.finality: Informal resolution represents final disposition and is not appealable

formal_process.applicability: All complaints not resolved through informal process or to which informal process doesn't apply or deemed inappropriate
investigator_responsibilities: Inform parties of right to be interviewed and provide evidence
Inform parties of right to advisor
Inform parties of right to determine participation level including right to remain silent
Obtain information, evidence, and witness identities from parties
Attempt to obtain information from identified witnesses
Ask relevant questions submitted by parties to any witness or party
Disclose information on need-to-know basis consistent with state/federal law
Keep supervisors/administrators/faculty informed and seek input when implementing resolution or discipline
Provide complainant, alleged victim, and respondent opportunity to review evidence and respond
formal_process.respondent_silence: If respondent remains silent without verbal/written response, absence considered general denial. Investigation proceeds and violation may be found if supported by preponderance of evidence.
formal_process.hearing_process: Interviews and information exchange through investigator, including opportunity to respond to evidence and provide questions for other party or witness, constitute hearing process for all discrimination/discriminatory harassment complaints other than Title IX Sexual Misconduct adjudicated under USG Policy to Prohibit Discrimination & Harassment, USG Standards for Institutional Student Conduct Investigation and Disciplinary Proceedings, and UGA Sexual Misconduct Policy.

investigation_report.draft_report: Prepared at completion and shared with parties. Parties have opportunity to review investigation materials upon receipt.
investigation_report.response_period: Parties have at least 10 business days to review file and submit written response
investigation_report.investigator_action: May continue investigation, modify report as appropriate, or finalize without further action based on responses
investigation_report.consolidation: Investigator may consolidate multiple allegations from same facts/circumstances or similar allegations against common party if known during investigation. Parties may request or object to consolidation but investigator has final determination authority.
investigation_report.pattern_consideration: May consider pattern of behavior if evidence known during investigation or prior investigation of similar conduct available
investigation_report.final_report: Provided to judicial body for adjudicating charges. Copy also provided to student/organization and alleged victim (where applicable).

resolution.timeline: Should be concluded within 120 business days of complaint receipt including exhaustion of appeal rights. EOO Director/NDAH Officer/Title IX Coordinator or designee advises parties if delayed and provides additional estimated time.
resolution.written_decision: EOO Director/NDAH Officer/Title IX Coordinator or designee notifies complainant and respondent in writing of investigation results. Disclosed only to parties and University officials as appropriate for remedial actions, discipline, sanctions, and appeal preparation.
resolution.effectiveness_determination: EOO determines whether remedial action is effective. Complainants encouraged to report reoccurrences of violating conduct and any retaliation.
resolution.remedial_measures_without_violation: May be imposed even in absence of violation if conduct found that may, if not addressed, rise to violation level.
resolution.unprofessional_conduct: Any unprofessional conduct or inappropriate behavior not covered by Policy referred to respective department or Human Resources

remedies.description: Where discrimination/harassment violation determined, University takes timely action to remedy effects
possible_remedies: Extensions of time to redo/complete academic work without academic or financial penalty
Changes to academic or employment arrangements, schedules, or supervision minimizing burden on complainant/victim
Provision of or referral to medical, counseling, and academic support services
Training/re-training on Policy and relevant topics for individuals or groups implicated
Other measures designed to repair negative impact

sanctions.determination_factors: Level of discipline and type/scope depends on severity and nature of discrimination/harassment, weight of evidence, and need to maintain safe and respectful environment. Also considers history of past discriminatory/harassing/retaliatory conduct, respondent's willingness to accept responsibility, and previous institutional response to similar conduct.
available_sanctions: Restriction or bar to entering certain University property or attending University events
Delayed degree conferral or revocation of degree

right_to_appeal.appeal_to: University President pursuant to this Policy
right_to_appeal.timeline: Within 10 business days after receipt of written decision notification. Must include all supporting materials at same time.
grounds: Material failure to comply with applicable procedures in NDAH Policy or to conduct reasonably thorough investigation
Partiality, bias, or conflict of interest by EOO Director/NDAH Officer/Title IX Coordinator or designee
Findings, if not overturned/modified, would result in substantial injustice to party including substantially inadequate or excessive sanction
New evidence not reasonably available to be presented during investigation
right_to_appeal.process: President's office notifies non-appealing party (if participated in investigation) and provides opportunity to respond in writing unless opted not to participate. President or designee may receive additional information if believed to aid appeal.
president_may: Affirm original finding but issue new sanction of greater or lesser severity
Remand case back to Equal Opportunity Office to correct procedural or factual defect
Reverse or dismiss case if procedural or factual defect cannot be remedied by remand
right_to_appeal.timing: Decision made within reasonable time. NDAH Officer/Title IX Coordinator, complainant, and respondent notified in writing.
right_to_appeal.implementation: During appeal, disciplinary action, sanction, or remedial/preventative measures may be implemented and enforced. Upon appealing party's request, President may in discretion temporarily suspend imposition while appeal pending.
right_to_appeal.finality: If appeal not filed within appeal period, findings become final and not subject to review
